body:
....and this is exactly why I think the long term correct solution is a wire format change - declare sizes and counts up front.

@ijuma - as InputStream is an abstract class rather than an interface I dont see a way of doing what you proposed that does not involve multiple inheritance?
~~An abstract class that extends InputStream may be a better option in that case~~. Actually that probably doesn't work. Let me check the diff more carefully.
`KafkaGZIPInputStream extends GZIPInputStream`  <--- i have to do this to get access to a protected field :-(

The other option is to drop this altogether :)
Perhaps the savings aren't sufficient to justify these concerns.
@granders @hachikuji I'd appreciate your feedback on this PR.
@guozhangwang @miguno @theduderog
@ewencp for review
@ijuma Thanks. So can this PR be closed now?

Thank you @ijuma for your comments. I guess I needed a bit of encouragement to figure out how to apply the change on Windows too. Tested under Windows Server 2016 Datacenter. Both ZK and Kafka start correctly. 

I also changed the README even though I thought it didn't need a change when I issued the PR. Let me know if the change sounds informative enough.

@ewencp thanks for the review. Updates made per comments, although I'm not sure the changes for the working directory are what you had in mind, just let me know.

EDIT:
I'm coupling the generation of the jmh uber jar/benchmark execution  in one script, with the idea that the benchmarks will always use the latest code.  This is why I'm relying on the execution directory location being the Kafka project directory or the jmh-benchmarks subproject directory.

Would it better to break out into two scripts:
1. A script that executes the benchmarks and can be kicked from any directory and would not rely on the ./gradlew call for building the uber jar.
2.  A second script that combines gradle uber jar creation and benchmark execution thus requiring the execution location being in Kafka project or jmh-benchmark subproject.

@ijuma no worries! thanks for your support on this PR!

ping @junrao @guozhangwang @ijuma @apurvam 

This patch modifies the server implementation to use the client-side `Record` objects for all internal processing. As you can see, this was a hefty bit of work, but fortunately most of the transformations are straightforward. The main thing to focus on is the implementation of `LogValidator`, which contains the offset assignment and record validation logic that was previously contained in `ByteBufferMessageSet`. I've been pretty careful to preserve the optimizations that were present previously (e.g. in-place assignment where possible), but don't take my word for it.

One quick note on naming. I've renamed the `Records` object and subclasses to `LogBuffer`. So `MemoryRecords` is now `MemoryLogBuffer`. The reason for this change was that it felt unintuitive for an instance of `Records` to be an `Iterable<LogEntry>`, with the `LogEntry` instances being the actual container for the records. A `LogBuffer` instead represents a range of the log and provides access to the log entries contained in it. That seemed more intuitive to me, but let me know if you agree or if you have other suggestions.

Slightly related, slightly tangential: is there a specific reason why we put the new broker-specific java classes under clients/ ?

I'm talking about stuff like:
FileRecords
LeaderAndIsrRequest / LeaderAndIsrResponse
StopReplicaRequest / StopReplicaResponse
UpdateMetadataRequest / UpdateMetadataResponse

@onurkaraman Yeah, I've wondered a bit about that also. I'd be OK moving `FileRecords` to the server if people prefer that. I was thinking one potential benefit is that it opens the door to adding persistence to the client, which some users have requested (we have an ancient JIRA for this, but the use case might not be too compelling). In the end, I decided it wasn't that much code, so having it in clients didn't hurt too much and it kept all record-related stuff close together, which may make it easier to share common pieces.
Can we see this merged ? +1

As of current implementation, when controller receives ControlledShutdownRequest, it will 1) for every broker in the cluster, for every partition on the broker which wants to shutdown, create an instance of PartitionStateInfo and add it to ControllerBrokerRequestBatch.,updateMetadataRequestMap; and 2) for every broker, for every follower partitions on the broker which wants to shutdown, send one MetadataUpdateRequst to that broker.

In order to shutdown a broker, the controller will need to instantiate O(partitionNum \* brokerNum) PartitionStateInfo and send O(partitionNum \* brokerNum) partitionStateInfo. This is not efficient. The broker should only need to instantiate O(partitionNum) PartitionStateInfo and send O(brokerNum) MetadataUpdateRequest.

Micro-benchmark results show that this optimization can reduce the time of processing ControlledShutdownRequest by 37%.
@becketqin @onurkaraman Can you review this?
I left some comments on the ticket itself.
LGTM

Thanks for the PR. It would be good to share more details on the performance improvement. In particular, I'm interested in the elapsed time improvement along with the number of partitions and brokers.
cc @junrao

@hachikuji, thanks for tackling this.

About the naming question, I also found it a bit confusing how we sometimes have an offset and sometimes don't when talking about records. That is, `MemoryRecords` includes the offset (and record size in the underlying buffer) for each record while `Record` does not. It all becomes clearer when one realises that `MemoryRecords` (renamed to `MemoryLogBuffer` in the PR) actually contains `LogEntry` instances, each being a pair of `offset` and `Record`.

One thing to think about is whether this fits with the other `Record` classes we have and whether that matters (maybe it doesn't). For example, `ConsumerRecord` contains the `offset` while `ProducerRecord` does not. Also, it would have been a bit easier to review if the rename had been done in a separate PR, but probably too late for that. :)

About having the classes in `clients`, I think that's OK as they are in an internal `common` package.

Ok, I didn't test the whole thing, just limited to checking this script:
_`IF ["%SCALA_VERSION%"] EQU [""](set SCALA_VERSION=2.10.6)

IF ["%SCALA_BINARY_VERSION%"] EQU [""](for /f) do (
    set FIRST=%%a
    set SECOND=%%b
    if ["%SECOND%"] EQU [""](set SCALA_BINARY_VERSION=%FIRST%) else (
      set SCALA_BINARY_VERSION=%FIRST%.%SECOND%
    )
  )
)
echo %SCALA_BINARY_VERSION%
`_

I set the SCALA_VERSION before hand, then run the above script, but I get nothing:
_`C:\Users\enoth\kafka>echo %SCALA_VERSION%
2.11.9
C:\Users\enoth\kafka>IF ["2.11.9"] EQU [""](set SCALA_VERSION=2.10.6)

C:\Users\enoth\kafka>IF [""] EQU [""](for /F) do (
set FIRST=%a
set SECOND=%b
if [""] EQU [""](set SCALA_BINARY_VERSION=)  else (set SCALA_BINARY_VERSION=.
)
) )

C:\Users\enoth\kafka>(
set FIRST=2
set SECOND=11
if [""] EQU [""](set SCALA_BINARY_VERSION=)  else (set SCALA_BINARY_VERSION=.
)
)

C:\Users\enoth\kafka>echo
ECHO is on.`_

I'm probably doing something wrong. @kkonstantine could you double check? Thanks.
@ijuma I moved the shared config literals to a `SharedConfigs` object and added an assert.
LGTM. Always nice when we can find and remove unused stuff!
LGTM

Hi @enothereska. Thank you for your review. 

I just pushed a fix for the second digit. In my previous runs it worked (it correctly started kafka) because I had only `*2.11*.jar` versions available as packages and `2*` would match `2.11`. Now the string split of both the first two version digits should work. 

(The issue was related to how variables are expanded within the `for` loop).

You can confirm its correct behavior just by running the following `bat` script as: 
`.\kafka-just-print-vars.bat Main`, 
which corresponds to the initial part of `kafka-run-class.bat`: 

``` Batchfile
@echo off

rem Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) ... etc

setlocal enabledelayedexpansion

IF [%1] EQU [] (
    echo USAGE: %0 classname [opts]
    EXIT /B 1
)


rem Using pushd popd to set BASE_DIR to the absolute path
pushd %~dp0..\..
set BASE_DIR=%CD%
popd


IF ["%SCALA_VERSION%"] EQU [""] (
  set SCALA_VERSION=2.10.6
)

IF ["%SCALA_BINARY_VERSION%"] EQU [""] (
  for /f "tokens=1,2 delims=." %%a in ("%SCALA_VERSION%") do (
    set FIRST=%%a
    set SECOND=%%b
    if ["!SECOND!"] EQU [""] (
      set SCALA_BINARY_VERSION=!FIRST!
    ) else (
      set SCALA_BINARY_VERSION=!FIRST!.!SECOND!
    )
  )
)

echo %SCALA_VERSION%
echo %SCALA_BINARY_VERSION%
```

It looks like there was no existing tests for TopicCommand list and describe. I've added a couple of tests for the marked for deletion "flag".

It might be worth following up in another JIRA with more tests for list and describe.

This latest version was my initial windows version too, but I ended up using percent expansion `%%` instead of delayed expansion `!!` because it seemed to work (again matching of jars happened because `2*.jar` matched `2.11*.jar`). Current version correctly expands the variable to `2.11*jar` (uses the two digits). 

You may try the above script, by first running `set SCALA_VERSION=2.11.8` in a command line prompt and try again by unsetting it with `set SCALA_VERSION=`. Finally you may test that the `else` branch within the `for` loop works by setting `set SCALA_VERSION=2`.

@yaojuncn New commits should trigger a new build. You can also close-reopen to force it. As for the issue itself, I think the reason we do not observe that behavior is that in common practices it was even-out with a large number of clients.
Closing the PR in anticipation of KIP-91.
LGTM. Merged to trunk.

One other small thing. In `AbstractCoordinator`, we have a background thread which is used for sending heartbeats. It looks like we have a handler for `InterruptedException` and `RuntimeException`. I'm wondering if we should now also handle `InterruptException` and call `Thread.interrupted()` so that the behavior is consistent, though it may not matter too much since we end up closing the thread anyway. Might also be nice to be able to have the same log message in both cases. What do you think?

By the way, we'll squash automatically when we merge, so don't worry about that.
Looks reasonable to me overall. cc @hachikuji
Good catch, we should also handle InterruptException. Calling Thread.interrupted probably doesn't matter, but it doesn't hurt to do it.
LGTM. Merged to trunk.
Discussed with @dguy offline and I think it makes sense to add this `close` function. Left one more comment above, otherwise LGTM.
@guozhangwang Should we make similar changes in `o.a.k.c.requests` or is this only for the old consumer?
One minor question. Otherwise, LGTM.
@becketqin Would be nice to get your feedback also. Put on the coffee and lose yourself in code review!
Ok, this works. LGTM
@miguno @theduderog Added a test that coveres the missing scenario.
Updated. Thanks @guozhangwang
LGTM. I kicked off a build of the Connect distributed test to be sure we didn't break anything. I'll merge after it finishes.

@ijuma Sure. Here is the experiment I did. I deployed a Kafka cluster of 150 brokers on 15 physical machines. 10 topics of 512 partitions each are created on the first 15 brokers (1 per machine). Then I trigger controlled shutdown by sending signal 15 to one broker. I have modified to code to get the time when the broker sends the ControlledShutdownRequst to when it receives ControlledShutdownResponse. With this patch, the time decreases by 37% from 3.8 seconds to 2.4 seconds.
Thanks.

This may not be the right place for this question, but I'll try anyways. If the metrics registry is private (which this PR aimed to expose), then what is the proper way to access the metric values collected by a KafkaStreams instance? e.g. if I wanted to poll the underlying consumer/producer/streams metrics registries, how would I do that in 0.10? I apologize if I'm just missing this in the documentation, I can't seem to find it though..
Would be good to add some test cases if it's not too much additional work.
Thanks for going the extra mile @kkonstantine and thanks for testing the PR @enothereska. LGTM.
Was this created by mistake? Can you close it, please?
I suggest we close this until we figure out a solution for `trunk` (#2113). Once we have that, we can discuss if backporting makes sense.
Makes sense.

Thanks, the updated change looks good. I'll test a bit and then merge if it all goes well. We already have a JDK 8 build: https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-jdk8. I'll update it to also build with Scala 2.12 once this PR is merged.
I haven't rebased or squashed this change?  Not sure what your normal practice is - I'll leave as is unless you direct otherwise.
We use a merge script that squashes all the commits into a single commit.
LGTM, merged to trunk.
Hi @becketqin and @ijuma, any other comments? Thanks!

I would also like to see at least one test. As a general rule, we should strive very hard to include tests whenever we fix bugs. Otherwise, we can easily regress again when the code is refactored or changed.
Started a system tests build: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/613/console

@miguno Yes, I read the monitoring docs, and specifically I'm trying to access the metrics (without JMX) listed here: http://kafka.apache.org/documentation#selector_monitoring. According to these docs, the metrics are exposed at the instance level: "The following metrics are available on producer/consumer/connector instances". KafkaStreams does not expose the metrics registry though, and I don't believe it exposes the underlying Producer and Consumer. I think I may be able to accomplish this by passing in a custom client supplier to the KafkaStreams constructor, and polling the underlying Producer/Consumer metric registries. It would be nice to just have the metrics registry exposed though for the KafkaStreams instance, but hopefully this will get resolved in 0.10.2.0 (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3701).

Anyways, I'm going to try passing in a custom client supplier (may just extend `DefaultKafkaClientSupplier` and see where that gets me), and may try extracting the metric values from the ProcessorContext (mentioned in the JIRA), but I'll post an answer to the SO post if I find a solution.
@ijuma @junrao Thank you for the reviews. Can you take a look at the updated code? Thank you!
Merged to trunk, thanks @dguy
Merged to trunk. Really appreciate your patience throughout the review process, and thanks a lot for your contribution @jeyhunkarimov !!

@ijuma @MayureshGharat 

Can we proceed this PR?
I'm looking for this PR to complete and make `buffer-exhausted-rate` metrics meaningful again as it's one of important metrics to me.
Even for other users experience I think this PR should be proceeded ASAP, as as of now users can misunderstand there was no buffer exhaustion by watching this existing, but not working metric always pointing zero.

The idea you two are discussing sounds reasonable to me too, +1.

Thanks for the patch. LGTM. The grouping potentially changes the ordering of the sending of the StopReplicaRequest for the same partitions. However, in this case, the ordering seems not important. It would be useful to add a comment about this.
